CARDINAL . According to sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act , a person who in a foreign state is suspected or accused of or sentenced for an act that is punishable there may be extradited to that state following a decision by the Government . Such extradition may be granted only if the act for which it is requested corresponds to an offence for which imprisonment for DATE or more is prescribed by NORP law .

CARDINAL . Sections CARDINAL - CARDINAL lay down certain limitations . Thus , an extradition request may not be granted for certain offences committed by members of the armed forces or for political offences . Furthermore , a person may not be extradited if , on account of his origin , belonging to a particular social group , religious or political views , or otherwise on account of political circumstances , he would run the risk , in the foreign state , of being subjected to persecution directed against his life or liberty or otherwise of a harsh nature . Also , the extradition can not take place if the person in question is not protected against being sent to a state where he would run such a risk . Finally , a request may be refused if , having regard to the person ’s young age , state of health or other personal circumstances , the extradition would run manifestly counter to the demands of humanity . In the latter case , regard should be had also to the nature of the offence in question and the interests of the requesting state .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL stipulates that an extradition request is submitted in writing to ORG , accompanied by the documentation on which the request is based .

CARDINAL . According to section CARDINAL , the Prosecutor - General gives his opinion in the extradition matter before the ORG takes a decision . If the person concerned does not consent to being extradited , the case is also examined by ORG .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL prescribes that ORG is to conduct the necessary investigation in accordance with the rules applicable to preliminary investigations in criminal cases . Coercive measures are subject to the general rules prescribed for criminal cases . However , there are also some more specific rules outlined in LAW , according to which a decision by a prosecutor to apply coercive measures must instantly be reported to a district court . Appeal against this court ’s decision lies directly to ORG .

CARDINAL . According to section DATE and DATE , ORG submits the case and the finished investigation , together with an opinion , to ORG . ORG then decides whether the extradition request may be lawfully granted . A hearing is held if it is considered necessary .

CARDINAL . Under LAW , the matter is reported to the Government when ORG has issued its decision . If ORG has found that there is a legal impediment to the extradition , the request may not be granted .

CARDINAL . A traditional , community - based gacaca system of tribunals was established in DATE to try people suspected of crimes during the DATE genocide , in order to resolve the enormous amount of such cases ( however , not the most serious , so - called “ category I ” cases – to which the applicant ’s case allegedly belongs – , which are still tried in the ordinary courts ) . The government ’s stated goal for the gacaca system was to ensure that those who had participated in the genocide were brought to trial , furthering the ends of justice , ending impunity and promoting national unity . The gacaca law provides for reduced sentences , including community service , for cooperation , and credit for time served .

CARDINAL . After a pilot phase when CARDINAL individuals were identified for prosecution for having participated in the genocide , the gacaca courts began trials nationwide in DATE . The trials have been public but there have been concerns about their fairness , among other things because of a perceived lack of impartiality and reports that defendants have not been given the opportunity to defend themselves . In addition , some courts have spent TIME hearing each case and poorly qualified , ill - trained and corrupt gacaca judges in certain districts have fuelled widespread distrust of the system . There have been reports of local gacaca officials and citizens abusing the process to pursue personal matters and settle grudges unrelated to the genocide , including making false accusations in order to acquire land . However , in some reported cases where judges had acted inappropriately , gacaca officials have intervened and held that the procedure had been illegal .

Pursuant to LAW bis of the Rules of Procedure and Evidence of the ORG and that court ’s case - law , a designated ORG may order referral to a ORG that has jurisdiction over the charged crimes and is willing and prepared to accept the case . In assessing whether a ORG is competent under LAW bis , it has to be established that it has a legal framework that criminalises the alleged conduct of the accused and provides an adequate penal structure . CARDINAL . On DATE the ORG decided for the first time to transfer an indicted genocide suspect for trial in GPE . In concluding that it was satisfied that the Government of GPE was now prepared to receive its first referral from the ORG , a ORG took into account the amendments that had been made to NORP legislation DATE and found that the issues which had led to the earlier refusals had been addressed to some degree in the intervening period .
CARDINAL . As regards the possible punishment imposed on a transferred suspect , the ORG stated the following ( at paragraph CARDINAL ) :

“ The ORG finds that the current penalty structure of GPE is adequate as required by the jurisprudence of the ORG as it no longer allows for imposition of the death penalty or life imprisonment with solitary confinement . The ORG is satisfied that the ambiguities which existed in previous LAW bis applications regarding the nature and scope of the sentence for accused persons in cases referred to GPE have been adequately addressed by GPE . ”
CARDINAL . It went on to draw the following conclusion as to the conditions of detention in GPE ( at paragraph CARDINAL ) :

“ The ORG notes that adequate detention conditions are guaranteed by LAW and considers that the Defence submissions that the conditions will be inadequate in practice are speculative at this juncture . The ORG expects that the monitoring mechanism will conduct regular prison visits to ensure that both the detention conditions and treatment of the Accused in detention are satisfactory , and that it will immediately report any concerns to both the Prosecutor and the President of the ORG . Thus , the ORG is convinced that the Accused will be detained in appropriate conditions if his case is referred to GPE . ”

CARDINAL . With respect to the main issue concerning the availability and protection of witnesses , the ORG first noted that it was not its role to determine whether the fears held by witnesses were legitimate , reasonable or well - founded but rather to assess the likelihood that the accused would be able to “ obtain the attendance and examination of witnesses on his or her behalf under the same conditions as witness against him or her ” ( as required by LAW , paragraph CARDINAL ( e ) of LAW ) if the case were to be transferred to GPE . As to witnesses residing in GPE , the ORG stated the following ( at paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) :

“ The Defence cites instances during DATE in which the ORG ’s defence counsel have complained that their witnesses were unwilling to testify because of fears of intimidation or harassment . [ ORG ] also refers to incidents in which defence witnesses in GPE have been jailed or victimised before or after testifying . Furthermore , many witnesses fear their appearance will lead to an indictment against them . Defence witnesses may fear being accused of “ genocidal ideology ” , a crime referred to in LAW but undefined under NORP law . It is the ORG ’s view that the concerns of witnesses within GPE regarding their safety have been addressed by changes to the law over DATE . ORG expects that GPE will ensure the safety of both prosecution and defence witnesses in a transfer case as has been stipulated in the new and amended laws .

ORG notes the previous findings by ORG in LAW bis decisions that witnesses in GPE may be unwilling to testify for the defence due to their fear that they may face serious consequences , including prosecution , threats , harassment , torture , arrest or even murder . The ORG notes that in the CARDINAL genocide cases tried in ORG of GPE , the defence in most cases was able to secure the attendance of witnesses even without the safeguards available to cases transferred from the ORG . It is logical to assume that with the amendments made to the laws regarding witness immunity , the creation of a new witness protection programme , and the safeguards imposed by ORG , ORG finding that witnesses may be unwilling to testify is no longer a compelling reason for denying referral .

Although the concerns expressed by the Defence are materially the same as those expressed by defence teams in past referral cases , GPE has shown the willingness and the capacity to change by amending its relevant laws over DATE . The amendment to LAW to include immunity for statements by witnesses at trial is a step towards allaying the fears of witnesses . This is complemented by the improvements made to ORG ( “ ORG ” which is sometimes also referred to as “ FAC ) and the creation of ORG ( “ WPU ” ) under the ORG as discussed below .

The ORG notes that in cases before the ORG some witnesses are still afraid of testifying despite the provision of multiple safeguards . The ORG is therefore satisfied that GPE has taken adequate steps to amend its laws in this regard . The full implementation of these additional measures mandated by this Chamber would likely guarantee a fair trial for the Accused .

The ORG further notes that the subjective fear of witnesses to testify can not be addressed without implementing adequate legal safeguards to allay such fears . Where laws can neutralise the reasonable fears of individuals , the ORG is of the opinion that they must be implemented and revised as needed . It is the considered opinion of this ORG that it is impossible to evaluate the effectiveness of a reasonable law in the abstract . Accordingly , the relevant NORP laws must be given a chance to operate before being held to be defective . ”
CARDINAL . The ORG then addressed the situation of witnesses residing abroad and noted , inter alia , the following ( at paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) :

“ The NORP states that all of its CARDINAL witnesses living abroad have indicated that they were not prepared to travel to GPE to testify or to appear before any NORP judge who might travel to their countries of residence . The ORG notes that following the DATE amendments to LAW , witnesses may now testify in CARDINAL more ways in addition to providing viva voce testimony before the relevant High Court in GPE : via deposition in GPE ; via video - link taken before a judge at trial , or in a foreign jurisdiction ; or via a judge sitting in a foreign jurisdiction .

At the outset , the ORG observes the use of any of these methods is not a right guaranteed to the Accused ( or to any other party ) . These procedures are intended as an exception to the general rule of viva voce testimony before the court , and whether to provide for any of these measures remains within the sole discretion of the trial court . The law is silent as to whether or not the adverse party can make submissions on such a request and does not establish any criteria that may guide a judge in his or her decision when facing such a request . The law also does not stipulate whether the decision on such a request is subject to appeal , and if so , under which conditions .

The ORG submits that in the present case the reasons put forward by Defence witnesses in their affidavits may well be rejected by a NORP judge . For instance , it doubts that a judge would consider valid a NORP fear for his or her security if brought to GPE for testimony , the fact that his or testimony would incriminate ORG ( “ RPF ” ) , or that he or she does not trust the NORP judiciary . Although the doubts expressed by the Defence are relevant the ORG concludes that they are speculative at this juncture .

With respect to the prospect that witnesses living abroad could testify by video - link , ORG has previously held that “ the availability of video - link facilities is not a completely satisfactory solution with respect to the testimony of witnesses residing outside GPE , given that it is preferable to hear direct witness testimony , and that it would be a violation of the principle of equality of arms if the majority of defence witnesses would testify by video - link while the majority of Prosecution witnesses would testify in person . ” However , with regards to the witnesses who live outside GPE , this ORG notes that , in addition to the possibility of hearing testimony via video - link , LAW amended Transfer Law allows testimony to be provided a ) via deposition in GPE or in a foreign jurisdiction , taken by a Presiding Officer , Magistrate , or other judicial officer appointed for that purpose ; or b ) before a judge sitting in a foreign jurisdiction for the purpose of recording such testimony .

The ORG argues that for its CARDINAL witnesses residing abroad , a judge sitting on the case would have to travel to CARDINAL different NORP countries to receive their testimonies meaning that the Accused would be absent for almost the entirety of his Defence case . The PERSON recalls the right of the Accused to be “ tried in his presence , ” as stipulated in LAW ) of [ LAW ] . The ORG notes the amendments to LAW which provide the option of hearing evidence from witnesses located outside GPE in order to ensure their protection . Even in an instance where the Accused wishes to exercise his right to examine or cross - examine a witness who is testifying in another location , he could avail himself of the video - link facilities already in place . Thus , there is no apparent impediment to the presence of the Accused during the sections of the trial that would take place outside GPE . The ORG finds that the Defence argument that the Accused would be absent for the majority of his Defence case untenable and that the possibility that witnesses will testify outside GPE can not be regarded as prejudicial to the right to a fair trial . ”

CARDINAL . The ORG further noted with satisfaction that , in addition to the witness protection programme administered by ORG ( “ ORG ” ) , GPE had recently taken steps towards the creation of a witness protection unit under the auspices of the judiciary ( “ WPU ” ) . However , the terms of reference and effectiveness of the new unit could not be evaluated as it had been established to assist witnesses in transferred cases only , and there had not been such a case yet ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . As to the availability of defence counsel , the ORG noted that many members of ORG had more than five years’ experience , that CARDINAL lawyers were enrolled in the ORG ’s list of potential counsel , that NORP lawyers were obliged to provide pro bono services to indigent persons and that there was a legal framework as well as a budgetary provision for legal aid . Consequently , the ORG was confident that defence counsel and legal aid would be available to the accused if transferred ( paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL and CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . While there were concerns about the working conditions for defence counsel – there had been instances of harassment , threats or even arrests of lawyers defending genocide suspects – the ORG noted that such incidents could be brought to the attention of the ORG or ORG and that LAW , as amended in DATE , granted lawyers immunity from prosecution for statements linked to their activities as defence counsel ( paragraphs CARDINAL and CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . On the issue of the independence and impartiality of the NORP judiciary , the ORG was of the view that NORP judges , as professional judges , benefited from a presumption in their favour that could not be lightly rebutted ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . The judges of ORG and ORG were considered qualified and experienced and in possession of the necessary skills to handle a transferred case ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . Furthermore , the NORP legal framework guaranteed the independence and impartiality of the judiciary ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . The submissions made in the case by the defence and by amici curiae in support of their contention that the judiciary lacked those qualities in practice , in the ORG ’s opinion , mainly concerned cases of a political nature and did not reflect the conditions of the trial or the charges faced by the accused ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . In addition , the information available to ORG did not give reason to conclude that the judiciary was unduly corrupt ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . In respect of most of the above issues , the ORG noted that there were additional safeguards in the monitoring and revocation mechanisms available under LAW bis . It requested ORG ( “ ACHPR ” ) , which had already agreed to the arrangement , to monitor Mr GPE ’s trial in GPE and declared that the Commission should bring to the attention of the ORG President any potential issues that may arise throughout the course of the proceedings ( paragraph CARDINAL ) . The ORG also emphasised that it was authorised to revoke the case from GPE as a last resort if necessary ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .
CARDINAL . The ORG ended its decision with the following conclusion ( at paragraphs QUANTITY ) :

“ Upon assessment of the submissions of the parties and the amici curiae , the ORG has concluded that the case of this Accused should be referred to the authorities of GPE for his prosecution before the competent national court for charges brought against him by the Prosecutor in the Indictment . In so deciding , the ORG is cognizant that it is taking a view contrary to the views taken DATE by ORG of this Tribunal where upon assessment of the facts before them , they concluded that those cases should not be referred to GPE .

ORG notes that , in the intervening period , GPE has made material changes in its laws and has indicated its capacity and willingness to prosecute cases referred by this ORG . This gives the ORG confidence that the case of the Accused , if referred , will be prosecuted consistent with internationally recognised fair trial standards enshrined in the Statute of this ORG and other human rights instruments . ORG is persuaded to refer this case after receiving assurances that a robust monitoring mechanism provided by the ORG will ensure that any material violation of the fair trial rights of this Accused will be brought to the attention of the President of the ORG forthwith so that remedial action , including revocation , can be considered by this ORG , or if applicable , by ORG .

ORG is cognizant of the strong opposition mounted by the Defence and certain amici curiae to the proposed referral . The ORG , however , considers that the issues that concerned the previous ORG , in particular , the availability of witnesses and their protection , have been addressed to some satisfaction by GPE in the intervening period and that any referral with robust monitoring would be able to address concerns that the Defence and the amici have expressed .

Before parting with this Decision , the ORG expresses its solemn hope that GPE , in accepting its first referral from this ORG , will actualise in practice the commitments it has made in its filings about its good faith , capacity and willingness to enforce the highest standards of international justice in the referred cases . ”
CARDINAL . The Referral Chamber ’s decision has been appealed against to ORG .

CARDINAL . Several requests by ORG for the extradition of persons suspected of various counts of genocide , crimes against humanity , murder or rape have been refused by the NORP courts . On DATE ORG of ORG declined to order extradition in the case of Bivugarabago . Following the ORG ’s approach in GPE and GPE , the ORG court considered that a NORP tribunal would be sufficiently independent and impartial , but that it would not guarantee a fair trial , in particular with regard to the appearance and protection of defence witnesses . Similar concerns led to extradition requests being refused by ORG of PERSON ( in the NORP overseas department of GPE ) on DATE in the case of ORG , by ORG of GPE on DATE in ORG and by ORG on DATE in GPE . The PERSON court reiterated the problems concerning defence witnesses and also found that the possible punishment of imprisonment for DATE in isolation contravened NORP public order as well as LAW .

CARDINAL . More recently , the appellate courts of GPE and GPE , on DATE and DATE respectively , refused extradition to GPE in the cases of PERSON and PERSON . The GPE court found that the crimes of genocide with which Mr PERSON was charged were not punishable under NORP law at the time when they were allegedly committed and that the “ ordinary crimes ” listed in the extradition request fell under a DATE statute of limitations . The court further had regard to the DATE arrest and detention in GPE of NORP attorney PERSON , defence counsel for several NORP suspects , on charges of “ genocide denial ” and concluded that Mr PERSON , if extradited , would not benefit from fundamental procedural guarantees and the protection of the rights of defence .

CARDINAL . Relying on the reasons for the refusals of the ORG to transfer cases to GPE , an appellate court in GPE / Main , on DATE , dismissed the requests for extradition of CARDINAL genocide suspects , PERSON and PERSON .

CARDINAL . On DATE the NORP ORG refused to extradite PERSON , a former NORP pastor , to GPE to face prosecution for genocide and murder . ORG referred to several ORG decisions and their conclusion that the right to a fair trial , in particular the right of the defence to call and hear witnesses , could not be guaranteed in GPE . According to ORG , it had neither any reason to question the conclusions of the ORG nor any grounds to assess the prevailing circumstances in GPE any differently than the ICTR . As GPE , by acceding to LAW , had committed itself to guaranteeing a fair trial to persons within its jurisdiction , ORG was of the view that NORP authorities could not , through their own actions , contribute to a trial in a foreign ORG which raised justified concerns as to whether the trial would be conducted in a fair manner .

CARDINAL . Instead , on DATE , Mr PERSON was charged with genocide and murder before the NORP courts , on the basis of universal jurisdiction laid down in NORP law . The trial began in DATE and , on DATE , after hearing witnesses in GPE , GPE and GPE , ORG found Mr PERSON guilty of genocide and of having murdered or incited others to murder CARDINAL persons . An appeal has been made against the conviction .

CARDINAL . In DATE the Government of GPE issued arrest warrants on suspicion of genocide in respect of CARDINAL men residing in GPE . Following an extradition hearing before GPE Westminster Magistrates Court , District Judge PERSON , on DATE , sent the matter to the Secretary of ORG who , on DATE , signed orders that the CARDINAL suspects be extradited to GPE for genocide proceedings . Appeals were made to ORG against the judge ’s decision and the Secretary of ORG ’s orders .

DATE . On DATE ORG ( Lord Justice Laws and Lord Justice PERSON ) delivered its judgment ( PERSON and others v. the Government of GPE and the Secretary of ORG for ORG ) . While it did not contest that there was a prima facie case against all CARDINAL appellants , on the principal issue of whether they would receive a fair trial in GPE its assessment of the facts and evidence differed sharply from that of LOC . ORG stated ( at DATE ) that the legal test for the fair trial issue CARDINAL LAW was “ whether the appellants would suffer a real risk of a flagrant denial of justice if they were extradited for trial in GPE ” . While LOC had correctly stated that the burden of proving that there was such a risk rested with the defence , he had erred in concluding that the appellants had to prove this on the balance of probabilities . According to ORG , this was not the accurate meaning of “ real risk ” ; rather , the term implied “ a risk which is substantial and not merely fanciful ; and it may be established by something less than proof of a PERCENT probability ” , thus the same approach as that taken in refugee cases ( paragraph CARDINAL ) .

CARDINAL . As to the merits of the issue of fair trial , ORG referred extensively to the conclusions drawn in the ORG transfer decisions . It noted that there was no specific provision in the procedural law of GPE for witnesses to give evidence via video - link and that , in the circumstances , there was at least a substantial risk that such facilities would not be available . Thus , ORG found it likely that the appellants would be unable to call supporting witnesses who declined to give evidence in person out of a professed fear of reprisals ( paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . Furthermore , having regard , inter alia , to a report by ORG of DATE and the testimony given by CARDINAL expert witnesses , ORG concluded that there was evidence of judicial interference by the NORP executive and that the appellants would suffer a flagrant denial of justice also in regard to the judiciary ’s impartiality and independence ( paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) . Accordingly , the appeals of all CARDINAL appellants were granted and their extradition denied . They were released from detention and can not be tried by the GPE courts .
CARDINAL . By a decision of DATE , ORG refused to extradite PERSON , a former NORP minister , to GPE .
CARDINAL . Following the refused request for a stay of deportation by ORG on DATE , ORG , on DATE , proceeded to deport ORG PERSON to GPE to face trial on genocide charges .

CARDINAL . On DATE the GPE ORG granted a request for extradition to GPE of PERSON , another genocide suspect . It first noted that there were reasonable suspicions against Mr PERSON for the crimes with which he was charged . It also considered that there was no reason to assume that , if extradited to GPE , he would be subjected to persecution that would threaten his life or freedom or otherwise be of a serious character . The court noted that the NORP police ( as well as , apparently , PERSON counsel ) had visited LOC ( where , if convicted , PERSON would be incarcerated ) and had found that the conditions there , including medical care , corresponded to international standards DATE a conclusion that had been shared by the ORG . Mr PERSON would also be able to receive regular visits from his family in GPE . The court thus concluded that the extradition would not run counter to humanitarian considerations or LAW .

CARDINAL . As to the main issue in the case – the fairness of the trial in GPE – the GPE court noted that improvements had been made in DATE to NORP legislation and administration – including the witness protection programmes – in an attempt to meet international fair - trial requirements . While PERSON counsel had claimed that problems persisted in practice in regard to the independence of the judiciary and the equality of arms , the court found that the legislative and other changes , as well as the possibility for observers to follow the trial , meant that there was no real risk that the trial would be unfair . There was thus reason to reach a different conclusion than that drawn in earlier ORG transfer decisions and in the judgment of the GPE ORG . The court also took into account that the NORP police had made CARDINAL investigative visits to GPE since DATE and had interviewed a total of CARDINAL witnesses in the country in regard to CARDINAL different cases . According to the report of the police , there had been no indication that the witnesses – whether testifying for or against the suspects in question – had been influenced or instructed by the NORP authorities to give particular statements or that they had been threatened in any way . Nor had any of the witnesses expressed a fear of the authorities or a reluctance to give testimony to the NORP police . In the court ’s view , these findings – together with the NORP witness protection guarantees and the alternative ways of giving testimony in cases transferred to GPE – indicated that Mr PERSON ’s fear that witnesses would refuse to give testimony on his behalf if his case were to be tried in GPE was not sufficiently justified .

NORP The GPE court further found that the ORG decision in the case of GPE had to be accorded great weight , in particular due to the ORG ’s knowledge of the conditions in GPE and since the threshold was higher for transfers from the ICTR ( the chamber had to be satisfied that the accused would receive a fair trial ) than for extraditions examined under LAW ( which were impermissible only if there would be a “ flagrant denial of justice ” ) . While the court noted that ORG had taken into account the monitoring it had ordered and the revocation mechanism it had at its disposal , the court stressed that the chamber had considered revocation only as “ a remedy of last resort ” and that it had generally been satisfied that the material changes in NORP legislation would render the trial fair .
